Award.AwardTitle: Electronic Many-body States with Topological Order
Award.AbstractNarration:
****Technical Abstract****

The two-dimensional electron gas confined to GaAs/AlGaAs heterostructures provides a model platform for the study of emergent phenomena brought about by strong electron-electron interactions in systems with reduced dimensionality. Recent theoretical work suggests that the two-dimensional electron system hosts novel phases of matter with previously unanticipated topological order and unusual quasiparticle statistics. The concept of topological order has been extended to many novel materials and it now permeates modern condensed matter physics. Our work focuses on questions of fundamental science of the two-dimensional electron gas such as inducing transitions between the various ground states of interest and the search for novel topological invariants. This project will constitute excellent preparation for a graduate student for his/her future academic or industrial career through the study of modern condensed matter physics and training in modern semiconductor processing, in conducting low level measurements, and in the use of cryogenic equipment. Undergraduate students will be introduced to concepts and techniques used in condensed matter physics.

*****Non-Technical Abstract****

Studies of the fractional quantum Hall effect reveal fascinating rules according to which the interacting quantum mechanical electrons arrange themselves. It has recently come to the fore that it is possible that certain fractional states may have a new type of internal degree of freedom called topological order. The concept of topological order may allow storing and manipulating quantum information in new ways and it has now conceptually been applied to many novel condensed matter materials. For this project we will study this hidden order in clean two-dimensional electron gases. The experiments will be at the confluence of modern semiconductor processing, nanophysics, and state-of-the art cryogenic technology. This project will support the education of a doctoral student in modern condensed matter physics which has historically provided excellent training for carriers both in academia as well as in high tech industries.

Understanding phases of matter has been an important endeavor both for scientific discovery and for technological applications. Examples include harnessing of steam power during the industrial revolution, the use of superconductors in MRI machines, and the use of permanent magnets as digital memories in the hard drives of personal computers. Until not so long ago all phases of matter could be categorized and understood in terms of a well-known umbrella theory called Landau’s theory.

 

In the last 20 years or so, however, it was realized that there are new phases which do not fit into Landau’s description. These phases are called topological phases and they catalyzed a new paradigm in the understanding the material world. The understanding of these topological phases became one of the important efforts in contemporary condensed matter physics. Theoretical work is largely focused on classifying the known topological phases, on searching for completely novel types of topological phases, and on finding applications of these states. It is thought that topological phases may find use in low dissipation electronics, spin electronics, and quantum computation.

 

Many of the prototype topological phases, such as the integer and fractional quantum Hall states, were discovered in the two-dimensional electron gas. The two-dimensional electron gas continues to be a fascinating system, since recent theories predict it hosts a large number of very unusual topological phases. Certain phases are thought to have curious non-commutative properties which do not exist in any other known system and which may be harnessed for novel schemes of quantum memories and computation.

 

Many of the unusual topological states, however, are fragile and can only be detected at extremely low temperatures. The PI has built a unique instrument capable of reaching 0.005 Kelvin, one of the lowest electronic temperatures in the world. By taking advantage of this unique instrument, for this project we conducted experimental research and education outreach addressing outstanding questions on the nature of topological order in electron fluids realized in the two-dimensional electron gas, specifically in the exotic fractional quantum Hall states. These measurements involved device fabrication using modern lithographic techniques of high quality samples grown via molecular beam epitaxy and transport measurements at ultra-low temperatures.

 

The most exciting outcome of this project has been the discovery of a new topological phase, a fractional quantum Hall state at the quantum number 3+1/3. At a first brush, one may think that this fractional state is related to cousin states such as the 2+1/3 and 1/3 fractional states. However, a more careful analysis of the strength of the 3+1/3 states show that it is anomalous. The most striking finding is that this state is stronger than the 3+1/5 state, in clear violation of expectations and of data on states such as the ones at the quantum numbers 2+1/3 and 2+1/5 states. The unexpected reversal of the strength is not yet currently explained, but it indicates that the leading theory does not capture the behavior of these groups of state, hence there is a chance that at least some of these states are of a novel origin.
